Highest score for the Final Exam this year is only 88. So I guess the Final Exam is somewhat harder than all the past years. Sorry about that. I guess it was a little overly interesting. Not to worry, probably won't make much of a difference to the final grades since I'm actually reading what everyone is writing and deciding on how much each student knows.

In case people are wondering, I typically try to set my exams so that the highest scorer should be able to score > 95. Most years I manage this. This is the first time I failed to do so in many years.

Halfway through grading the Finals. Results thus far are not too optimistic. I suspect that I might have been overly creative this round? >_< 

Not sure if people have been looking at the solutions? Aren't the solutions pretty simple?

What's clear is that quite a few students are hardworking -- but I think it worked against them. I think they got too caught up in the Little Red Riding hood past question and couldn't think differently. Clearly, the prof is not so kind as to repeat a past year question?
Quick poll: people did think the Finals was interesting right? Especially after reading the solutions? I spent a lot of effort setting it.
Interesting is one thing. Dificulty is another
I hope you appreciate my creativity from reading my solutions. :-)
Always love your questions Ben Leong. Made me actually like programming
For the enjoyment of the ex-students. :-)

Basically I want my students to learn Quicksort, but we don't have time/space to fit that into the main course. So I decided to split it into 2 parts over 2 Final Exams. First I teach non-in-place last year and this year, I teach in-place. In-place also happens to be more convenient for translation to C -- in case people want to understand the logic on how I set the exam.

Well, future students will now learn Quicksort when preparing for the Final Exams. How cool is that? :)
Anyone who has ideas on what I should teach the next batch of students in the Final Exams is welcome to PM me. :-)
I like your last question. Especially the part that says "repent now".

Now I'm at Q4. Many students gave up on in-place Quicksort and took a -2 penalty on Part (B) by doing naive non-in-place Quicksort. However, what they didn't understand is that non-in-place is v hard to do in C, so that who do this will buang Part (E). >_<

One champion got the DP question (Q3E) correct, but Q3D wrong.

Good point. I guess if someone forgot to submit yesterday. This would be the last chance.

Some students complained about my lectures in the midterm survey. They say that there's a gap between the lectures and the problems that you are meant to solve. Well, that is intentional. 

That "gap" is called learning. 

And the midterm is for me to gauge whether you have managed to cross that "gap". I'm almost done grading and I'm v v unhappy with the results this year. Quite a number of you will be coming for a re-test, notwithstanding that the midterm is significantly easier than that for past years. 

But you see, the point of the midterms is not about hard or easy. What it does is measure learning and it did the job really well. Those who did well, good job (sadly, there aren't too many of you). Those who didn't, please go and read the solutions carefully once I'm done updating them with feedback from my grading. Also, please do and try out the past year midterm exams. 

My midterms are as you would have figured out by now, somewhat different from what you are used to in the 'A' Levels. They actually test where your brain is wired right and occasionally, they try to teach you something. Doing them is good for your brain, so please do it.

“Whether it’s the pioneer in the Conestoga wagon or someone coming here in the 1920s from southern Italy, there was this idea in America that if you worked hard and you showed real grit, that you could be successful,” he said. “Strangely, we’ve now forgotten that. People who have an easy time of things, who get 800s on their SAT’s, I worry that those people get feedback that everything they’re doing is great. And I think as a result, we are actually setting them up for long-term failure. When that person suddenly has to face up to a difficult moment, then I think they’re screwed, to be honest. I don’t think they’ve grown the capacities to be able to handle that.”

Many (most?) of you probably won't end up writing software for a living, but if you survive CS1010FC/X, you would minimally have learnt how to persevere in spite of challenges and getting stuck. :-)

data.message: Hi everyone, I hope that you all agree with me that CS1010FC is a good introduction to programming. The enrollment for CS1010FC is however a bit low. I think we have capacity to clear a lot more than the current 50 or so students a year. Anyone has ideas on how we can promote the module so that more students can take the course next year?
Must let the students know that it can be used to replace CS1010 when sch term starts cause from personal experience not many incoming students know about this
"If you don't learn Python in 1010FC now, you'll have to learn C in 1010".
Conduct a trial
Have a free 'limited access' public account for people to try it out? When they realise how fun it is they'll be more likely to join
I second Darius's point. Be explicit that you can count the MCs and give u a headstart when university starts
Send us to speak to the juniors hahaha

Usually NS ppl either too busy or too lazy to find out abt ibloc by 2nd year. By the time they find out, registration close alr. So longer term solution would be to have a super early registratiom system/express interest form when they are offered a place in SOC (start of NS) and still bother to plan for the future.
Use adwords?Probably can experiment as a new form or model in school

Inform them that CS1010/E is a compulsory core mod for SoC and most FoE students and they can clear earlier. And also the new Tuition Fee Rebate where they can get back their iBLOC module fees if they graduate within 4 years (rebate does not apply to misc fees though). http://www.nus.edu.sg/registrar/edu/UG/fees.html#TuitionFeeRebatePolicy

Anyone willing to help with the publicity? Actually, we probably need a team. If you think that CS1010FC was helpful to you (i.e. you think it was a good idea to clear CS1010 before School starts), pls help us reach out to your juniors so that it would benefit them too! :-)

Not so sure about promoting it on a modular credit / requirement basis, but I think another approach could be to highlight how fun & fulfilling the class was. Is there any way to highlight the cool assignments that we finished, like the hunger games AI coding, or 2012 assignment? :)

Yeah maybe can advertise how fun it was to code cool things like the different patterns/rules. I still think the biggest drawing factor will be how essential this module is to clear for FoE and SoC students and sharing the potential benefit of such a choice.
Probably it will be useful to be listed under Mindef E-Prep Programme, I saw NTU's version, but I didn't see NUS ones.
That's because NTU got no MC carry over. Plus Mindef doesn't subsidise for NUS. The eprep on NTU I also think not by teaching faculty

data.message: So far, no one has said he will be coming down on Tues to look at the scripts. If I don't hear from anyone by tomorrow (Mon) 5 pm, we will not have a script checking session on Tues. If you want to come check your script, you can post a comment here.

Nobody is here leh. Last call. Will close shop in 20 mins.

I am finally done with CS1010FC. :-) Highest score on the Final Exam was 97, but for most students, the Final Exam was likely a horror story. >_< *sigh* I also don't understand why so many students did so badly. Ah well. 

The solutions have been updated (with minor bug fixes) and with the marking scheme: http://coursemology.org/courses/149/materials/files/3814. 

Those who want to see your scripts can drop by at my office (COM2, #03-20) from 11 am to 12 noon on Tuesday 23 Jun 2015. It is highly unlikely that your grades will change as a result of you checking your scripts. This is just to give you the chance to see where you went wrong, in case the solutions aren't good enough. Please drop me an email if you're planning to turn up. If no one is turning up, the session will not be held. 

Some of you (esp. the A students) can pretty much guess at your grade. Most of those who did badly in the Finals will likely receive a better final grade that what you would expect given the rather disastrous Finals. Good news for those worrying about passing the class. I am not planning to fail anyone this Semester (but you are all welcome to drop CS1010FC if you enjoy C and want to take CS1010 next Sem :-) ).  

Thanks for being great students. I wish you all a v good break and all the best for your future studies.

"Some recent research suggests that, by thinking about death so often, the Bhutanese may be on to something. In a 2007 study, University of Kentucky psychologists Nathan DeWall and Roy Baumesiter divided several dozen students into two groups. One group was told to think about a painful visit to the dentist while the other group was instructed to contemplate their own death. Both groups were then asked to complete stem words, such as “jo_”. The second group – the one that had been thinking about death – was far more likely to construct positive words, such as “joy”. This led the researchers to conclude that “death is a psychologically threatening fact, but when people contemplate it, apparently the automatic system begins to search for happy thoughts”." 

At my last lecture, I also suggested that you think about death, even though at your age, death seems distant. The main reason is that I think the thought experiments I suggested will help you think about what you are doing in perspective.
data.name: Bhutan’s dark secret to happiness

data.message:
"A body of research on conceptions of ability has shown two orientations toward ability. Students with an Incremental orientation believe ability (intelligence) to be malleable, a quality that increases with effort. Students with an Entity orientation believe ability to be nonmalleable, a fixed quality of self that does not increase with effort.

The “entity orientation” that says “You are smart or not, end of story,” leads to bad outcomes—a result that has been confirmed by many other studies. (The relevance for math is shown by researchers at Oklahoma City who recently found that belief in inborn math ability may be responsible for much of the gender gap in mathematics.)"

Applies to programming too! CS is Applied Math.

data.message: "Programming is about solving problems. But before you write any code, you need to be clear on how to solve the problem. One skill good programmers have is the ability to break the problem down in smaller and smaller parts, until each part can be easily solved. But it is not enough simply to find a way to solve the problem. A good programmer finds a way to model the problem in such a way that the resulting program is easy to reason about, easy to implement and easy to test."

Yeah man.. I think I just figured out why:

When the interpreter sees this line:
new_if(x>5, print(x), p(2*x))

it starts to evaluate print(x) which causes it to print x.. Then it proceeds to evaluate p(2*x) which causes it to print 2*x and so on.. It never has the chance to enter into the function new_if..

data.message:
"Previous research has shown that activating a stereotype can influence subsequent behavior in a stereotype-consistent way. The present research investigates the role of self-efficacy beliefs in this effect. Specifically, we demonstrate that being primed with the stereotype of professors increases knowledge confidence compared to being primed with a less educated profession (Experiments 1 and 2), and that these higher self-efficacy beliefs result in higher performance at a general knowledge test (Experiment 2). These findings are corroborated in Experiment 3 that shows that participants primed with the stereotype of athletes show higher persistence in a physical exercise than participants primed with a stereotype less associated with persistence. Again, behavior was mediated by self-efficacy beliefs. The findings are in line with the active-self account (Wheeler & Petty, 2001; Wheeler, DeMarree, & Petty, 2007) that proposes that priming with a stereotype influences a person's behavior through altered self-representations."

Not sure if this really helps, but the PE is tomorrow. Those who are coming, maybe you can try convincing yourself that you're the prof before you start and let me know if it helps. Those who are not coming tomorrow (good work!), you still have the Finals next Thurs to try this. :-)

data.message:
"But there's another reason to learn to code, whether or not self-coding computers are on the horizon. And it's this: learning to code is a good way to learn to think.

Some of the very properties of computer languages that can be cumbersome and difficult to master — such as the need to specify everything explicitly, to consider exceptions, to understand recursion and to think through downstream consequences — are among the most valuable for thinking. It's precisely because human thinking is so often underspecified, and human language so often ambiguous, that designing computers that can code from human instruction is such a hard problem for AI. But it's also why learning a formal, expressive language is so valuable for human minds."
data.name: Learn To Code, Learn To Think

data.message: #thelastlecture
Prof with eyes opened lol. \

"You walk away thinking that "1+1" is all you were taught, but you don't recognize that "1+1" is simply all you learned. You were supposed to master much more by working long hours on your own with the book, wrestling with difficult concepts, and coming to office hours to ask the inevitable questions that you couldn't resolve on your own. But you didn't. You had other classes, other priorities, and other obligations. You didn't love the subject enough to immerse yourself in it. Your professor understands. In fact, she's probably even sympathetic to the point that she gives you a C- when you really deserve an F (or a B+ when you really deserve a C).

Later, you find out that 3 students scored near 100% on the exam, and you assume they must be math geniuses and dismiss the possibility that you could ever duplicate the feat when the truth is (or might be) that you could do just as well if you were willing to spend 15 hours per week on the class rather than 4."

In case you have the same question tomorrow during your Practical Exam.... here's the answer. For CS1010FC, you should be better off, since the gamification actually "forces" you to do work. Still, much depends on you. All the best!

data.message:
"The main event is not getting a number to tell you you are worthy. The main event is pulling your crap together and making hard choices and sacrifices when things seem impossible.  It is finding hope in the hopeless, courage in the chasm, guts in the grave.

What you need to see is that every time you take the easy way out, you are building a habit of quitting. And it will destroy your future and it will annihilate your happiness if you let it.   Our society cares nothing for quitters.  Life will let you die alone, depressed, and poor if you can’t man or woman up enough to deal with hardship.  You are either the muscle or the dirt.  You either take resistance and grow stronger or blow in the wind and erode.

As long as you are in my life, I am not going to let quitting be easy for you.  I am going to challenge you, confront you, push you, and coach you.  You can whine.  You can throw a tantrum.  You can shout and swear and stomp and cry.  And the next day, guess what?  I will be here waiting — smiling and patient — to give you a fresh start.  Because you are worth it."
data.name: What Students Really Need to Hear

"Both Bock and Schmidt are adamant that most people should go to college but that skills and experience are more important than the stamp of expertise. Bock says Google is looking for the kinds of projects candidates completed or what they accomplished at an internship.

I honestly can’t remember the last time someone asked me what my major in college was. If you want a job at Google (or some other prestigious company), don’t focus so much on your major, and make sure you graduate with all the skills and experiences you need to do awesome things in the world."

data.message:
"If you really think about learning, there are some master disciplines which unlock all the others.  They are philosophy, history, mathematics, language (reading/writing), and science (mainly mastery of the scientific method).  These disciplines form the core of learning and comprise the engine of its expression.  The student who gains proficiency in these areas will maintain, for virtually the rest of his/her life, the capacity to learn new things and to organize those new things within the context of the older things.  The learning that takes place in these areas does not really expire.  It does not become dated.  It is a fund that maintains its value.  The same is not necessarily true of knowledge gained in professional programs."

I believe that there is actually some truth in this statement -- and the reason is the following: what you have to learn in university is not STUFF, but HOW TO LEARN. The liberal arts people aren't learning anything particularly practical and so the focus is not on learning stuff, which they also know is not practical, but on the learning itself. Think about this. Most of you will probably suffer some in CS1010FC and many of you who will suffer will probably not be doing CS or programming for a career. Keep in mind that the value in the suffering is in the training of the mind, of grit and perseverance.
data.name: This College Professor Has A Message For Liberal Arts Majors
